NETM, Network management (Appl. Inc.)
Initialisation: at reset (power on of ECU):
wind up counters:
CTR_DLY_IF_CFT = NC_CAN_500_MS
T_CAN_OFF_DLY = NC_CAN_750_MS
update wakeup reason for NWM output:
STATE_POP_NWM_H_EMS_LSB_CAN = 0x1
STATE_POP_NWM_H_EMS_MSB_CAN = 0x0
At IGK off to on:
set sleep indication to 0 because of Ignition key is on:
LV_SLP_IDC = 0
wind up counters:
CTR_DLY_IF_CFT = NC_CAN_500_MS
T_CAN_OFF_DLY = NC_CAN_750_MS
lv_if_cft_msg_miss_kl15_off = 0
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_H_ENA)
LV_WKU_STAT_OFF = 0
ENDIF
At End of power latch (before ECU shutdown):
IF T_PWL > C_T_MAX_PWL
THEN
LV_NWM_H_EMS_LOC_ACT = 1
ELSE
LV_NWM_H_EMS_LOC_ACT = 0
END
At IGK on to off:
LV_NWM_H_EMS_LOC_ACT = 1
At End of power latch (before ECU shutdown):
force shutdown of Can2 and FR transceiver and in case NWM_H
is not active also CAN1.
Functioncalls for FR transceiver
FrTrcv_SetTransceiverMode(FRTRCV_TRCVMODE_NORMAL)
FrTrcv_ClearTransceiverWakeup
are called to set the FR transceiver to SLEEP mode
there had to be a time gab of 100us between this calls and the
xecond call of
FrTrcv_SetTransceiverMode(FRTRCV_TRCVMODE_SLEEP)
Activation: ever
Deactivation: never
Recurrence: 10 ms

NETM, Network management (Appl. Inc.)
switch (STATE_MAIN_NETM)
case NETM_STATE_NORMAL_OPERATION
nothing to do in this state
case NETM_STATE_PWL_OPERATION
C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_H_ENA
THEN
// For NWM_H, sleep indication bit is set to 0. Sleep indication is set due
to NWM driver request
LV_WKU_STAT_OFF = 0
LV_SLP_IDC = 0
ELSE
IF C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_STB_ACK_ENA
// For indirect network management, sleep indication bit is set direct
to 1.
IF CTR_DLY_IF_CFT > 0
CTR_DLY_IF_CFT - -
IF TOUT_CTR_IF_CFT_1 > NC_T_PAS_CAN
LV_IF_CFT_MSG_MISS_KL15_OFF = 1
// a timeout is detected 500ms after Ignition Key = 0FF
ENDIF
ENDIF
ELSE
IF NC_ENG_CONF = NC_ENG_CONF__DS
THEN
LV_SLP_IDC = 1
ELSE
LV_SLP_IDC = 0
ENDIF
ENDIF
ENDIF
case NETM_STATE_READY_SLEEP
IF C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_H_ENA
THEN
IF LV_CAN_MSG_SND_ENA = 0
AND LV_NWM_H_MSG_SND_ENA = 0
THEN
LV_SLP_IDC = 1
// NWM_H driver has no more request to send can Messages, set sleep indication
bit
ENDIF
ELSE
IF C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_STB_ACK_ENA
THEN
LV_SLP_IDC = 1
IF T_CAN_OFF_DLY > 0
THEN
T_CAN_OFF_DLY - -
ENDIF
ELSE
// nothing to do for other Network managements
ENDIF
ENDIF
case NETM_STATE_SLEEP

Handling of LV_NWM_H_EMS_LOC_ACT:
This bit is set at IGK on to off and if previous DC was longer than C_T_MAX_
PWL
Current storage handling:
Information about the LV_NWM_H_EMS_LOC_ACT is stored in CAN Fly channel. This
channel is stored at the end of PWL. In the update routine it is checked if T_
PWL > C_T_MAX_PWL. In this case, a 1 is stored in PWL, otherwise 0.
During PWL and if T_PWL > C_T_MAX_PWL the storage of this fly channel is triggerd
one times.
NWM_H PWL CDN before CAN-wakeup: STATE_PWL_CDN_NWM_H_EMS_CAN
This function is only used in NETM-High Projects:
Calculation of STATE_PWL_CDN_NWM_H_EMS_CAN has to be done in 10ms function to indicate, which lock
conditions are present before ECU enters NWM_H state.
This state describes why ECU was in post operating phase / powerlatch, when NWM_H requested a wakeup.
If the ECU is in post operating phase (LV_PWL = 1) and a wake up from NWM_H is requested, this state signalizes
if the ECU was in PWL and which PWL_LOCK_CDN was set, for information. So this state is calculated if LV_PWL
= 1 and it is frozen if a wakeup is detected LV_WKU_CAN = 1 or LV_IGK = 1.

Function description:

Formula section:
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 0
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_H_ENA)
THEN
IF (LV_EFP = 1)
OR (ACTION_NETM_TActMinEna = 1)

and if the ACTIVE MIN time is not elapsed
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1

ELSE

THEN

mode, because of this configuration has no wakeup capability from powerlatch

59.2.4 ACTION_NETM_ReadySlpCdn
Function description:
This Action checks the conditions for transition into ready sleep mode
Formula section:
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 0
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_H_ENA)
THEN
IF LV_EFP = 0
AND ACTION_NETM_TActMinEna = 0
THEN
// NWM_H enters ready sleep mode if there is no request for the fuel pumps and if the ACTIVE MIN time
elapsed
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1
ENDIF
ELSE
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_STB_ACK_ENA)
THEN
IF (LV_STB_ACK = 1 AND LV_VAR_CAN_IF_CFT = 1)
OR NOT((LF_CAN_MSG_RCN_ENA_0 & NLF_CAN_MASK_IF_CFT_ENA_1) == NLF_CAN_MASK_IF_CFT_ENA_
1)
OR (TOUT_CTR_IF_CFT_1 >= NC_T_PAS_CAN AND LV_VAR_CAN_IF_CFT AND CTR_DLY_IF_CFT = 0)
OR (LV_IF_CFT_MSG_MISS_KL15_OFF AND CTR_DLY_IF_CFT = 0)
OR (LV_VAR_CAN_IF_CFT = 0)
THEN
// indirect network management enters ready sleep mode if:
// gateway message is not enabled by calibration
// the sleep acknowlege for gateway is set
// or if a gateway timeout occurred
// or if there is no gateway coded via variant coding
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1
ENDIF
ELSE
// all other managements are every time ready to sleep
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1
ENDIF
ENDIF
RETURN PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK

59.2.5 ACTION_NETM_SlpCdn
Function description:
This Action checks the conditions for transition into sleep mode
Formula section:
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 0
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_H_ENA)
THEN
// NWM_H enters sleep mode by direct request from NWM_H driver. Entering
the sleep mode by ECU SW is NOT POSSIBLE!
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 0
ELSE
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_STB_ACK_ENA)
THEN
IF (TOUT_CTR_IF_CFT_1 >= NC_T_PAS_CAN AND LV_VAR_CAN_IF_CFT AND CTR_DLY_
IF_CFT = 0)
OR (LV_IF_CFT_MSG_MISS_KL15_OFF AND CTR_DLY_IF_CFT = 0)
OR (LV_VAR_CAN_IF_CFT = 0)
OR NOT((LF_CAN_MSG_RCN_ENA_0 & NLF_CAN_MASK_IF_CFT_ENA_1) == NLF_CAN_
MASK_IF_CFT_ENA_1)
OR (T_CAN_OFF_DLY = 0)
THEN
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_STB_ACK_WKU)
THEN
IF (LV_WKU_CAN_ENA = 0)
THEN
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1
ENDIF
ELSE
// indirect network management enters sleep mode if:
// gateway message is not enabled by calibration
// a gateway timeout occurred
// or if there is no gateway coded via variant coding
// or if delay time for shut down of can is elapsed
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1
ENDIF
ENDIF
ELSE
// all other managements are every time ready to sleep
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1
ENDIF
ENDIF
RETURN PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK
59.2.6 ACTION_NETM_WkuCdn
Function description:
This Action checks the conditions for can wakeup during powerlatch
Formula section:
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 0
IF (C_TYP_CONF_NETM = NC_NETM_NWM_H_ENA)
THEN
IF (LV_CAN_WKU_STAT = 1)
AND (LV_WKU_STAT_OFF = 1 OR ACTION_NETM_TDlyInhPin() = 1)
THEN
// a wakeup occurred if the INH Pin of can transceiver is 1 AND there was
enough time to let the pin reach 0 after shutting down the transceiver or the
pin has been 0 after shutdown
PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK = 1
ENDIF
// all other network managements don?t have a wakeup capability during powerlatch
ENDIF
RETURN PRM_TRAN_CDN_OK

59.2.12 ACTION_NETM_StopCanTransceiver
This Action sets the can transceiver into sleep mode
the "GOTO SLEEP MODE" has to stay at least for 80us or for C_T_WAIT_CAN_HW_SDN us to be sure that the
can transceiver reaches the sleep mode
If the Can transceiver driver is available (NLC_NETM_CAN_DR_AVL == ACTIVE), ACTION_INFR_DeactivateCanTrcv
is used to stop the can transceiver.
For the second transceiver LV_ERR_TMP_MU_MC is check. If LV_ERR_TMP_MU_MC = 0, the NDIS wire allows to
disable the transceiver. If the LV is not checked, the Transceiver driver losts its syncronisation and it is no more
possible to shut down CAN2 transceiver.
If no can transceiver driver is available the can transceiver is controlled direct via IO Pins.
59.2.13 ACTION_NETM_StartCanTransceiver
This Action initialize the can transceiver (PT-Can and CCP Can) an set them into normal mode
If the Can transceiver driver is available (NLC_NETM_CAN_DR_AVL == ACTIVE), ACTION_INFR_ActivateCanTrcv
is used to activate the can transceiver.
otherwise the can transceiver is controlled direct via IO Pins.
59.2.14 ACTION_NETM_StopCcpCan
Shut down CCP can transceiver
Like the PT Can transceiver, the CCP can transceiver had to stay at least 80us in state "GOTO_SLEEP"
If the Can transceiver driver is available (NLC_NETM_CAN_DR_AVL == ACTIVE), ACTION_INFR_DeactivateCanTrcv
is used to stop the can transceiver.
For the second transceiver LV_ERR_TMP_MU_MC is check. If LV_ERR_TMP_MU_MC = 0, the NDIS wire allows to
disable the transceiver. If the LV is not checked, the Transceiver driver losts its syncronisation and it is no more
possible to shut down CAN2 transceiver.
If no can transceiver driver is available the can transceiver is controlled direct via IO Pins.

� General Information
This module manage the correct communication-behavior when ECU goes to sleep respectively wakes up.
There are 3 different types of Networkmanagement:
1. NWM-High: Networkmanagement as described in chapter ?Function description?
2. Stand by acknowledge: On KL15-off event ECU sends a sleep request to Gateway and goes to sleep,
when Gateway respond this request by acknowledge-message. ECU wake up on KL15 event
3. No NWM: ECU stop sending on KL15-off event and start sending on KL15-on event
These types can be calibrated by c_typ_conf_netm.

59.3.6 ACTION_NETM_TActMinEna
PRM_LV_ACT_MIN_ENA = 0
#IF (NC_NETM_ACTIVE_MIN_ENA == ACTIVE)
#THEN
IF (CTR_NWM_H_MIN_TX_MSG <NC_NWM_H_MIN_TX_MSG)
THEN
// not all sending messages are send
PRM_LV_ACT_MIN_ENA = 1
ENDIF
#ELSE

PRM_LV_ACT_MIN_ENA = 1
ENDIF
#ENDIF
RETURN PRM_LV_ACT_MIN_ENA

The image is not a Simulink diagram. It's a configuration table with associated function descriptions for the NETM CAN module (Network Management).

## Function

The document describes the configuration parameters for the NETM (Network Management) CAN module, specifically the NM-high driver (NWM_H). This module is responsible for network management functions within a CAN (Controller Area Network) communication system.

## Inputs

The "inputs" in this context are the configuration values that are applied to the NETM CAN module. These values are detailed in the table and include:

*   `kNmhBusOffRecoveryTime1`: Bus-Off recovery time of first bus-off.
*   `kNmhBusOffRecoveryTime2`: Bus-Off recovery time of consecutive bus-offs.
*   `kNmhCycleTime`: Cycle time of NmhTask().
*   `kNmhDiagStartTime`: Time after power-on until the active CAN self-diagnostics is started.
*   `kNmhMsgCycleTime`: Cycle time of the transmitted Network Management Message.
*   `kNmhMsgTimeout`: Timeout for the successful transmission of NM-messages.
*   `kNmhNumberOfChannels`: Number of channels on which the NM-High is used.
*   `kNmhPrepareSleepTime`: Time to wait before preparing for sleep mode.
*   `kNmhRepeatMsgCounts`: Number of Network Management Messages to be sent in sub-state Repeat Message.
*   `kNmhTimeoutTime`: Timeout of the reception of Network Management Messages.
*   `kNmhTxRecoveryTime`: Tx object recovery time.
*   `kNmhTxTimeoutTime`: Tx object timeout time.
*   `kNmhWaitBusSleepTime`: Bus calm down time.

## Outputs

The "outputs" here are the behavior and performance of the NETM CAN module as a result of the configured parameters. For example, the network management protocol will behave differently based on the timeout values, cycle times, and recovery times set in the configuration. Specific outputs include when nodes enter sleep mode, when bus-off conditions are handled, and the timing of network management messages.

## Logic Flow

There isn't a "logic flow" in the traditional sense of a Simulink diagram. Instead, the image defines configurable parameters for the NETM CAN module.

1.  **Initialization:** The NM-high driver (NWM_H) is initialized with configuration provided by the customer.

2.  **Parameter Configuration:** Each parameter in the table is configured based on the specific requirements of the application. These parameters influence various aspects of network management, such as:

    *   **Bus-Off Recovery:** Defines the recovery times after bus-off errors.
    *   **Cycle Times:** Defines the execution rates of network management tasks and the transmission rate of NM messages.
    *   **Timeouts:** Sets timeouts for various operations, such as message transmission and reception.
    *   **Sleep Management:** Configures the behavior related to sleep mode entry.

3.  **Network Management Operations:** The NETM CAN module uses the configured parameters to perform network management functions, including:

    *   Managing the CAN bus state (e.g., bus-off recovery).
    *   Sending and receiving Network Management (NM) messages.
    *   Handling diagnostic requests and responses.
    *   Controlling sleep mode entry and exit.

The "Formula section" provides example settings and relationships:
* `kNmhNumberOfChannels = 1` indicates NM-High is used on a single CAN channel.
* `kNmhCycleTime = 10ms` shows the task cycle rate is 10ms.

## Function

The primary function of this stateflow diagram is to manage the Network Management (NETM) states of a system. The NETM task handles transitions between different power modes: Normal Operation, PWL (Power Wake-up Listen) Operation, Ready to Sleep, and Sleep. The state transitions are triggered by various conditions related to the ignition key state (LV_IGK) and other NETM signals (ACTION_NETM_*Cdn).

## Inputs

Based on the diagram, the key inputs appear to be:

*   **LV_IGK:** This likely represents the status of the ignition key (e.g., 0 = key off, 1 = key on).
*   **ACTION_NETM_ReadySlpCdn:** A signal indicating that the system is ready to sleep.
*   **ACTION_NETM_PwlStateCdn:** A signal related to the PWL operation state.
*   **ACTION_NETM_WkuCdn:** A signal that seems related to a wake-up event or condition.

*   **ACTION_NETM_ReadySlpCdn:** A signal indicating that the system is ready to sleep.
*   **ACTION_NETM_PwlStateCdn:** A signal related to the PWL operation state.
*   **ACTION_NETM_WkuCdn:** A signal that seems related to a wake-up event or condition.
*   **ACTION_NETM_SlpCdn:** A signal related to entering Sleep.
*   **NWM_H driver:** external request signal

## Outputs

The primary output of the stateflow is implicitly the current state of the Network Management (NETM) system, represented by the `NWM state`. This state affects other systems that rely on network connectivity and power management. The outputs would thus be:

*   **NWM state:** (NORMAL MODE, NORMAL MODE oder REPEATE MESSAGE, READY TO SLEEP oder PREPARE TO SLEEP, SLEEP)

## Logic Flow

1.  **Normal Operation:** The system starts in the "Normal Operation" state (`NWM state: NORMAL MODE`).

2.  **Transition to PWL Operation:** If `LV_IGK = 1` (ignition key is on), the system transitions to the "PWL Operation" state (`NWM state: NORMAL MODE oder REPEATE MESSAGE`).

3.  **Transition to Ready to Sleep:**  From "PWL Operation," the system transitions to the "Ready to Sleep" state (`NWM state: READY TO SLEEP oder PREPARE TO SLEEP`) when `ACTION_NETM_ReadySlpCdn` is true.

4.  **Transition to Sleep:**  From "Ready to Sleep," the system transitions to the "Sleep" state (`NWM state: SLEEP`) either by a `NWM_H driver` signal or by `ACTION_NETM_SlpCdn`.

5.  **Transition from Sleep to PWL Operation:** From "Sleep," the system transitions back to "PWL Operation" when `ACTION_NETM_WkuCdn` becomes true.

6.  **Transition from PWL Operation to Normal Operation:** If `LV_IGK = 0` (ignition key is off), the system can go from the "PWL Operation" state back to "Normal Operation".

7.  **Transition from Ready To Sleep to Normal Operation:** If `LV_IGK = 0` (ignition key is off), the system can go from the "Ready to Sleep" state back to "Normal Operation".

The diagram describes a state machine that manages transitions between different power modes based on ignition key status and network management signals. The states represent the operational modes of the network management system, and the transitions define the conditions under which the system switches between these modes.
